Experience Executive Director Stanford University 2006  – Present (9 years) As Executive Director of Communication Services, I'm responsible for architecting, implementing and maintaining the Stanford University Data, Voice and Video networks. Communication Services is responsible for providing Data, Voice and Video services to all academic and administrative buildings as well as to the student residences. Communication Services also designs and operates the firewall infrastructure that protects Stanford’s administrative systems.  
 
Since joining Stanford University, I've led the initiative to implement a new 10Gbps SUNet backbone network and a campus wide departmental firewall service, which provides network security to 300 individual departmental networks. Additionally, I have successfully launched several new fee based network services to the Stanford community. Summary I bring new things to life in transportation and mobility.  
 
Professionally, my background is in transportation, design, media and startups. I am the Executive Director of the Revs Automotive Research Program at Stanford University and I am an appointed lecturer at the Stanford School of Engineering. Since 2011, I have developed and launched classes at Stanford in Mechanical Engineering and the Hasso Plattner Institute of Design (d.school). I am also an advisor and investor in startups that are changing transportation. In the broadest sense, I help people bring new ideas to life in mobility. 
 
Email: reillybrennan (at) gmail . com 
 
Twitter: @reillybrennan 
 
Newsletter: I send out a weekly newsletter called Future of Transportation which is an inside look at all the things I’m seeing in connected cars, autonomous vehicles, transportation venture capital, mobility and the like. You can sign up for it here: http://tinyletter.com/transportation/ Experience Executive Director, Revs Automotive Research Program Stanford University January 2012  – Present (3 years 8 months) Stanford, CA The Revs Program at Stanford established a new trans-disciplinary field connecting the past, present and future of the automobile, autonomy, transportation and mobility. My role as Executive Director is to drive growth of the program inside and outside of Stanford. We are fortunate to be able to work with great researchers who have brought many cool things to life, whether that is new scientific discovery, autonomoous vehicles, or the many startups that Stanford students have launched within mobility. Appointed Lecturer Stanford University 2013  – Present (2 years) Stanford, CA I have a lecturer appointment at Stanford University's School of Engineering. I teach in the Hasso Plattner Institute of Design (aka the d.school) and have launched various courses including  
ME236: "Understanding Superfans and their Heroes"​ with Michael Sturtz, taught in the Stanford d.school. 
ME200: "Understanding Historical Significance: The Automobile"​ with David Kelley and Jon Feiber, in which our students present a trophy as judges in the Pebble Beach Concours d'Elegance 
ME302A: "Introduction to Automotive and Transportation Innovation at Stanford" which is a survey of all the great transportation innovations underway at Stanford.  
 
My courses bridge the fields of transportation and design thinking. As head of content I led strategy with the VP of the business unit and operationally I managed AOL Autos as Editor in Chief. General Manager, Automotive NextScreen August 2007  –  December 2008  (1 year 5 months) As GM I was responsible for content, audience and P&L of Nextscreen's automotive properties including Winding Road. Editor, Winding Road NextScreen January 2006  –  August 2007  (1 year 8 months) As Editor of Winding Road and with the support of a very good team I launched the property out of beta and we went from 90k MAU to 1.1M MAU in 12 months. From there I moved to the business side as General Manager. Trackside communications manager General Motors 2003  –  2006  (3 years) Corvette C5-R and NASCAR. Summary Specialist in automotive environmental issues -- communication and marketing. 
 
Michael Coates is an internationally recognized expert in the field of automotive environmental issues. He has been a key participant in automotive marketing and publishing for more than two decades. His marketing and public relations experience includes work with Chrysler, the U.S. Council for Automotive Research, General Motors, Mercedes-Benz, BMW, VW, BF Goodrich, Neste Oil and others. His projects have included national product launches, trade and consumer show programs, media relations, promotions, and market positioning. 
 
In addition, Coates has more than a dozen years of full-time experience as an editor and writer with a variety of automotive and general interest publications and broadcast outlets including Petersen Publishing Company (now part of Source Interlink), trade magazines, plus newspaper and television news reporting. Other public relations and marketing experience includes work with high-tech companies in the Internet, telecommunications, and advanced technology sectors, working with major national public relations agencies, boutique firms and independently. He currently serves on the board of Western Automotive Journalists, a San Francisco Bay Area group of automotive writers. 
 
Specialties: Extensive knowledge of advanced automotive technology and alternative energy technology.  
 
Strategic thinker who has organized public relations and public affairs campaigns for Fortune 100 companies.  
 
Extensive and deep relationships with key influencers in the California environmental, regulatory and media communities. Summary Specialist in automotive environmental issues -- communication and marketing.

Treasurer Western Automotive Journalists July 2008  – Present (7 years 2 months) Board Member, current treasurer, co-chair of "Future Cars, Future Technology" Summit, former president, former Media Day co-chair Member Congregation Shir Hadash 1993  – Present (22 years) Former board representative-communications Co-chair of "Silicon Valley Reinvents the Automobile" Western Automotive Journalists November 2012  –  March 2013  (5 months) Blackhawk Museum Western Automotive Journalists (WAJ), in conjunction with SAE International’s Mid-Cal Section, hosted an event, “Silicon Valley Reinvents the Automobile” on Tuesday, March 5th, 2013, at the Blackhawk Museum in Danville, CA. The subject was nothing short of a reality check on the evolution of the automobile since Silicon Valley entered the car business. Almost all of the automakers worldwide have established a presence in Silicon Valley, listening and learning what the tech community it up to. 
 
The program featured displays and demonstrations from auto companies. Displays outside the museum included Stanley, the fully-automated Volkswagen Touareg that won the DARPA Grand Challenge in 2005, a Volkswagen Jetta TDI that has been running on algae-based biofuel for the past year, a 2013 Ram with the UConnect system, named the 2012 Technology of the Year by AOL Autos and a Mercedes SLK featuring the Digital DriveStyle app. Inside the Museum, Nissan displayed the Oporo robot "cars." 
 
The panel discussion, moderated by Wired Magazine’s Damon Lavrinc, includes Catherine Lovazzano, a San Francisco-based “futurist” (Senior Manager, Consumer Trends and Foresight) for Chrysler/Fiat; Dan Phillips, who’ll be giving the first public report on Solazyme‘s year-long 100% algal-based biodiesel project with Volkswagen, Dr. Kal Mos of Mercedes-Benz Research & Development North America will discuss the connected car research of his Palo Alto lab.

Summary Jason Wingard, Ph.D., is Dean and Professor of the School of Continuing Education at Columbia University. Previously, he served as the Chief Learning Officer at Goldman Sachs, a multinational investment bank. In this role, he was responsible for the strategy and implementation of thought leadership and management development solutions for the firm's global workforce and clients. 
 
Dr. Wingard is also President and CEO of The Education Board, Inc., a boutique management consulting firm. 
 
Previously, Dr. Wingard served as Vice Dean of the Wharton School, University of Pennsylvania, where he led Executive Education and oversaw one of the world's largest providers of leadership development for managers and executives. He also served as Senior Vice President of Regional Markets at ePals, Inc. and President & CEO of the ePals Foundation. ePals, Inc. is the world’s leading provider of school-safe collaborative learning products. 
 
Prior to joining ePals, he was Executive Director of the Stanford Educational Leadership Institute (SELI) at Stanford University. Dr. Wingard has also served in a variety of cross-functional executive roles for organizations including the Aspen Institute, the Vanguard Group and Silicon Graphics, Inc. (SGI). 
 
Dr. Wingard currently serves on the Board of Directors for Touchstone Education, Inc., the Zoeza Institute, and the Education Board Foundation. He also is co-founder of, and serves as Senior Advisor to, the Philadelphia Youth Sports Collaborative. 
 
He holds a BA in Sociology (Organizational Behavior & Social Psychology) from Stanford University, a MA in Education from Emory University, an EdM in Technology in Education from Harvard University, and a doctorate degree in Education, Culture, and Society (Corporate Education) from the University of Pennsylvania. He lives with his wife and five children in Chestnut Hill, PA.
